(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 21:33, 3 August 2011 (UTC)

revision.text:
Under Voicing there is a section titled Notes. There are some minor grammatical errors here. I found them to be distracting while I was studying. Sorry.
Minor grammar corrections: Under Note 1: the word "there're" should be "there are". I have never ever seen "there are" written as a contraction. Under Note 2 and 3, in the first line of each, the word "doesn't" should be "don't". In both cases, the verb needs to agree with a plural subject. She/He/it doesn't but they don't.
The information regarding when k changes to g and ğ certainly clears up many questions that I had regarding renk and rengi. It also has given me the information that I need to apply this rule to other words where k follows a consonant. Thank you. [[User:Tekirkedi|Tekirkedi]] ([[User talk:Tekirkedi|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Tekirkedi|contribs]]) 22:19, 3 August 2011 (UTC) * See [[wikt:there're]] * I corrected "doesn't"s *I will also add your example (renk > rengi). Thank you for feedback :) [[User:Srhat|Srhat]] ([[User talk:Srhat|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Srhat|contribs]]) 14:22, 5 August 2011 (UTC)

Use the background image property to create a linear or radial gradient. Use the linear-gradient keyword to create a linear gradient. Use -moz-, -o-, -webkit-, and -ms- as a prefix to the linear-gradient keyword for Mozilla, Opera, Webkit, and Microsoft browsers respectively. #corpnav, #searchbar { color: #999; background-image: -o-linear-gradient(top,rgb(100,100,100),rgb(200,200,200)); /* for Opera */ background-image: -moz-linear-gradient(top,rgb(49,49,49),rgb(7,7,7)); /* for Mozilla */ background-image: -webkit-linear-gradient(top,rgb(100,100,100),rgb(200,200,200)); /* for Webkit */ } ==References== [http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/css3-linear-gradients/ CSS3 Linear Gradients] {{BookCat}}

== Chloroplasts == [[File:Chloroplast II.svg|400px|right]]
Chloroplasts are organelles that contain '''chlorophyll''', the green pigments that make plants green. They are often called '''plastids''', though plastids and chloroplasts are not exactly the same thing—a chloroplast is a special kind of plastid that photosynthesizes. Chloroplasts do lots of things, but their main function is '''photosynthesis'''.
Plant cells, and some protists have chloroplasts, though animal and fungal cells lack them. Prokaryotes do not have chloroplasts (or any other organelles), though some can carry out photosynthesis, its cell acting like one big chloroplast. In most cases, chloroplasts are green.
Chloroplasts are cellular generators. They take in carbon dioxide and water, and release sugar and oxygen. This process is called '''photosynthesis'''. Mitochondria then use the sugar and oxygen to carry out cellular respiration, producing energy.
Mitochondria are essential parts of many eukaryotes, but they are useless without oxygen. Therefore, chloroplasts are extremely important. They produce breathable air for life.
Like mitochondria, chloroplasts have their own DNA. Scientists also think chloroplasts are descended from a kind of bacteria, called '''cyanobacteria'''. Cyanobacteria are the photosynthetic bacteria we mentioned earlier. In early stages of Earth, cyanobacteria produced oxygen for their friends, the ærobic bacteria ('''ærobic''' means they use oxygen). Some of these ærobic bacteria later migrated into a eukaryotic cell, becoming mitochondria. The cyanobacteria followed, becoming chloroplasts. All eukaryotic cells contain mitochondria, but only plants and algæ contain chloroplasts, so scientists think mitochondria came first.
[[File:Plagiomnium_affine_laminazellen.jpeg|thumb|400px|left| Chloroplasts visible in the cells of Plagiomnium affine — Many-fruited Thyme-moss. Small green dots are chloroplasts, hexagons are plant cells. Chlorophylls contained in chloroplasts are so small to be distinguished in this picture.]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: /* Totternhoe Castle */ Corrected spelling of Totternhose to Totternhoe
revision.text:
There are three castles of note in the county of Bedfordshire. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" |- ! width="12%" | Name
! width="10%" | Type
! width="8%" | Date
! width="10%" | Condition
! width="10%" | Ownership ([[../Key/]])
/ Access ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | Bedford Castle | Keep and bailey | 110112th century | Archaeological remains | HAL[[Image:UKAL icon.svg]] | Largely demolished following well-documented 8-week siege by Henry III, with around 2000 men, in 1224. |- | Someries Castle | Fortified manor house | 140115th century | Fragmentary remains | HC[[Image:CL_icon.svg]] | Brick-built, never completed, on site of earlier building, ruined gatehouse and chapel survive, remainder demolished 1742. |- | Totternhoe Castle | Motte and bailey | 110112th century | Earthworks | HAL[[Image:UKAL icon.svg]] | Motte and 3 baileys in prominent position. |} ===Bedford Castle=== [[Image:Castle Hill, Bedford - geograph.org.uk - 646086.jpg|225px|thumb|right|Remaining motte of Bedford Castle]] Bedford Castle was a medieval castle built after 1100 by Henry I. The castle played a prominent part in civil war of the Anarchy in the mid-12th century and in the First Barons' War at the start of the 13th century. The castle was significantly extended in stone, although the final plan of the castle remains uncertain. Henry III besieged the castle in 1224 the siege lasting eight weeks and involving an army of as many as 2,700 men. After the surrender of the castle, the king ordered its destruction. Although partially refortified in the 17th century during the English Civil War, the castle remained a ruin until the urban expansion in Bedford during the 19th century, when houses were built across much of the property. Today only part of the motte still stands, forming part of an archaeological park built on the site between 2007 and 2009. {{clr}} ===Someries Castle=== [[File:Someries Castle.jpg|225px|thumb|left|Someries Castle]] Someries Castle (sometimes spelt Summeries Castle) is a Scheduled Ancient Monument, in the Parish of Hyde, near the town of Luton, Bedfordshire. It was built in the 15th century by Sir John Wenlock. Although always referred to as a castle it was actually a fortified manor house. The name of "Someries Castle" was derived from William de Someries, who had a residence on this site, but the title "castle" is contentious since it hardly describes the structure to which it is applied. The site was acquired by Wenlock in 1430 and building the mansion commenced. The house is unique in that it is regarded as one of the first brick buildings in England. The house was never completed by Wenlock, and was partly demolished in the 18th century. The brickwork can still be seen in the remains of the gatehouse, incorporating the chapel and lodge, which still stands today. The remains of the original manor house and/or the earlier Norman Castle are now visible only as earthworks that outline the plot where the house originally stood, although remains of the gatehouse to the actual manor house and the chapel that was connected to it, are still partially standing. Some bricks from the manor house were used to build the nearby farm houses in the 17th century. {{clr}} ===Totternhoe Castle=== [[File:Totternhoe Castle - geograph.org.uk - 323991.jpg|225px|thumb|right|Totternhose Castle]] Totternhoe Castle is a medieval castle in Bedfordshire. It overlooks the village of Totternhoe and was built during the Norman period, probably during the years of the Anarchy. It is a motte-and-bailey design, with two baileys rather than the more usual one. A wide ditch protects three sides of the castle, with the fourth protected by the edge of the chalk hill on which the castle is situated. {{BookCat}}

Used in a category to hide a namespace and/or prefix that is standard to all the members of the category, for improving readability.
=== Usage === {{tlx|hide prefix|prefix to be hidden}}
Using {{tlx|hide prefix|Template:}} in a category with templates will remove <tt>Template:</tt> from the links to all of them. See, for instance, [[:Category:Text formatting templates]]. <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Category namespace templates|{{PAGENAME}}]] </includeonly>

{{tmbox|type=content|text='''Please do not add inappropriate external links to books.'''
External links that you have added have been considered inappropriate by your fellow contributors. Books are intended to be read without the need for external references. Rather than adding external links, particularly those which are for advertising or promotion, please instead expand books to include any missing information. If you feel the external link should be added to a book, please discuss it on the module's talk page rather than re-adding it. See the [[Wikibooks:Welcome|welcome page]] to learn more about Wikibooks. Thank you. --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jomegat|contribs]]) 17:47, 4 August 2011 (UTC) }}

page.title: Talk:IB Cultural Anthropology/The Nature of Anthropology/Paradigm of Anthropology

revision.text:
--Need for improvements--
This is not a very well written article as of the time of my writing today, August 4, 2011. I hate to say that, while not taking the time to suggest improvements, but it's true. I'm a student of the philosophy of science, and virtually every sentence here fails to reflect common understandings in the field. Key problems waiting to be addressed include: (1) the inaccurate definition of paradigm, which, in particular, does not reflect the (several) conceptions of paradigm explicated by Kuhn in the postscript to the second edition of his famous book; (2) the inaccurate presentation of paradigm shift, either as Kuhn originally presented it or as Kuhn and others subsequently modified it; and (3) the wholly inadequate linkage of such concepts to the philosophy of anthropology in general and cultural anthropology in particular.[[Special:Contributions/134.173.195.201|134.173.195.201]] ([[User talk:134.173.195.201|discuss]]) 20:16, 4 August 2011 (UTC)

geograph.org.uk - 1192634.jpg|90px]] | HC[[Image:CL_icon.svg]] | South wall remains, with two of the original four turrets. |- | Prior Castell's Tower | Tower house | 140115–16th century | Substantially intact | [[File:Pele Tower, Inner Farne Island - geograph.org.uk - 2010838.jpg|90px]] | ENT[[Image:NTE icon.svg]] | |- | Prudhoe Castle | Castle | 110112–14th century | Ruins | [[File:Prudhoe Castle 2.jpg|90px]] | EH[[Image:EH icon.svg]] | |- | Shilbottle Tower | Pele tower | 140115th century | Restored | [[File:Geograph-2156100-by-Alexander-P-Kapp cropped.jpg|90px]] | Private | Incorporated into a vicarage. |- | Shortflatt Tower | Pele tower | 130114–15th century | Restored | [[File:Gateway and private road to Shortflatt Tower - geograph.org.uk - 684189.jpg|90px]] | Wedding venue | Incorporated in later house. |- | Thirlwall Castle | Tower house | 130114th century | Fragmentary ruins | [[File:Thirlwall Castle - geograph.org.uk - 127117.jpg|90px]] | HAL[[Image:UKAL icon.svg]]
Northumberland National Park | Built with stone from Hadrian's Wall. |- | Twizell Castle | Tower house | 140115–18th century | Fragmentary ruins | [[File:Twizel Castle - geograph.org.uk - 1202957.jpg|90px]] | HAL[[Image:UKAL icon.svg]] | Medieval ruins incorporated in 18th century folly. |- | Warkworth Castle | Keep and bailey | 110112–14th century | Ruins | [[File:Warkworth Castle interior, 2007.jpg|90px]] | EH[[Image:EH icon.svg]] | Although looked after by English Heritage, partly owned by the Duke of Northumberland. |- | Whittingham Tower | Pele tower | 120113–14th century | Restored | [[File:Whittingham Tower - geograph.org.uk - 1332545.jpg|90px]] | Private | Converted for use as almshouses in 1845. |- | Whitton Tower | Pele tower | 1386c.1386 | Intact | | Holiday accommodation | Near Rothbury, well-preserved. |- | Willimoteswick Castle | Fortified manor house | 150116th century | Ruins | [[File:Willimoteswick Bastle, Haltwhistle - geograph.org.uk - 124371.jpg|90px]] | Private, farm | Incorporates remains of earlier building, largely rebuilt 1900. |} [[File:Twizel Castle - geograph.org.uk - 1202957.jpg|thumb|Twizell Castle]] '''Twizell Castle''' stands on a bend of the River Till at Tillmouth Park, Northumberland. Below it, the medieval Twizell bridge spans the river. The gardens of the castle contain the earthwork remains of the once lost medieval village of Twizell, whilst the massive ruin presents the remains of an 18th century castle which was never completed. A medieval tower house which once stood on the site was, in 1415, held by Sir John Heron. This was destroyed by the Scots in 1496, and the estate was sold by the Herons circa 1520 to a member of the Selby family. A survey in 1561 reported only the remnants of a tower house and a barmkin. Of the medieval structure, blocked windows, a chamfered doorway and the original north-east angle quoins are all that remains visible now. In 1685 Sir Francis Blake purchased the estate from the widow Selby for £1,944, plus an annuity of £100, and the Blake family lived on the estate until 1738 when they moved to nearby Tillmouth Hall. From about 1770, he worked on the recreation of the castle as a Gothic Revival mansion, designed by architect James Nesbit of Kelso to be five levels tall. Despite some forty years of work, the project was never completed. When in 1882, the Blake's built a new mansion at Tillmouth Park much of the incomplete Twizell Castle was demolished and the stone used in the new construction. The house is now a two-story folly. Rectangular in plan, with circular towers on the angles and two wings on the north side, the basement rooms in the main block are stone and brick-vaulted as a precaution against fire. {{BookCat}}

There is only one castle in Buckinghamshire. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" |- ! width="12%" | Name
! width="10%" | Type
! width="8%" | Date
! width="10%" | Condition
! width="10%" | Ownership
/ Access ! class="unsortable" | Notes ([[../Key/]]) |- | Boarstall Tower | Fortified manor house | 1312c.1312 | Fragment | ENT[[Image:NTE icon.svg]] | Moated site, gatehouse survives, altered 16–17th centuries, remainder of house demolished 18th century, converted to house 20th century. |} ===Boarstall Tower=== [[Image:Boarstall_Tower.jpg|right|thumb|350px|Boarstall Tower]] Boarstall Tower is a 14th-century moated gatehouse located in Boarstall, Buckinghamshire and now, with its surrounding gardens, a National Trust property. The gatehouse was built by John de Haudlo in 1312 and is all that remains of Boarstall House, a fortified manor house that was demolished in 1778. Although it was updated in 1615 for use as a banqueting pavilion or hunting lodge, it retained its mediaeval belfry, cross loops and crenellations. The exterior and many rooms are essentially unchanged. The property is tenanted with limited opening arrangements. Exterior rooms remain virtually unchanged since 1615. {{BookCat}}

== Gary DeGregorio == I'm the Chief Technology Officer for Decision Innovation (http://www.decisioninnovation.com) in Algonquin, Illinois. Please go to (http://www.linkedin.com/in/garydegregorio) for information about me. You can email me at gary.degregorio@decisioninnovation.com (mailto: gary.degregorio@decisioninnovation.com).
== Purpose == Much of my WikiBook editing will be focused on book content related to decision making, decision management, decision frameworks, knowledge management, and innovation.

page.title: Patterns Of Screen Writing/Planning/Law Of Variation

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/Nav}}</noinclude> ==Law Of Variation== {{Rquote|right|fly like a butterfly sting like a bee|Muhammad Ali}}
<noinclude>__TOC__</noinclude>
===Intent=== To maintain the viewer's interest and maximize the emotional effects.
===Also Known As=== Avoid cliché, Avoid Stereotypes, Develop Symbol systems, Rhythm, Intensification, Irony,
===Motivation=== If for some reason the viewer's interest is lost, the easiest fix is to introduce change. This applies to almost any aspect of screenwriting.
===Applicability===
*Emotions :*Emotional Highs and Lows (as discussed below) *Exposition :*Transpose Exposition and action *Scenes :*Long and Short scenes *Conflict :*Present opposing points of view
===Structure=== *Variation – do not repeat, recycle material, adopt clichés, use stereotypes, change scene length. *Intensification – conflict, action, risks, stakes, pace, and intensity all need to become more intensive. *Reverse Expectation – "fly like a butterfly sting like a bee"; before success, the deepest abyss. *Surprise – the unexpected is the acme of variation. *Maximize - the scope of variation and you will be maximizing its effect.
====Technique 1. Inside Outside==== Follow an indoors scene with an outdoors scene.
{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/ex}}
====Technique 2. Short Long==== Follow an short scene with a long scene.
{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/ex}}
====Technique 3. Action Exposition==== Follow action with a exposition.
{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/ex}}
====Technique 4. Emotional Highs And Lows==== * Maximise the emotional effects of scenes by planning a sequence of increasing climaxes. * As you build up a climax use a wide mix of emotional effects.
{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/ex}}
====Technique 5. Covert Overt==== Show and later explain. This technique is used in some of the greatest movies. The moral message is dramatised subtly symbolically in several ways. Once the viewer has become emotional invested in the premise, it will be restated enunciated explicitly, unequivocaly in dialogue or voiceover. The latter version of the message might be controversial, but the use of variation helps to carry it past the viewers resistance.
{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/ex}}
====Technique 6. Character's strength and Weakness==== To make a character more accessible to the audience you need to show incidents in which expose his strength his weakness and how he develops to over come his weakness. This variation of success and failure due to a character flaw is another element whose variation should be planed to increase the viewer's stakes. Such incidents should have a unifying theme and should refer to the moral premise.
{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/ex}}
===Participants=== ===Collaborations=== ===Consequences=== ===Uses & Abuses=== ===Related Patterns===
<noinclude>{{:Patterns Of Screen Writing/refSection}}</noinclude>
